error.msg: The scope of the variable 'dataRef' can be reduced.
error.verbose: The scope of the variable 'dataRef' can be reduced. Warning: Be careful when fixing this message, especially when there are inner loops. error.msg: Class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__connect_socket_82_base' which is inherited by class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__connect_socket_82_bad' does not have a virtual destructor.
error.verbose: Class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__connect_socket_82_base' which is inherited by class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__connect_socket_82_bad' does not have a virtual destructor. If you destroy instances of the derived class by deleting a pointer that points to the base class, only the destructor of the base class is executed. Thus, dynamic memory that is managed by the derived class could leak. This can be avoided by adding a virtual destructor to the base class.

error.msg: Class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__connect_socket_82_base' which is inherited by class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__connect_socket_82_goodG2B' does not have a virtual destructor.

error.msg: Variable 'data' is assigned in constructor body. Consider performing initialization in initialization list.
error.verbose: When an object of a class is created, the constructors of all member variables are called consecutively in the order the variables are declared, even if you don't explicitly write them to the initialization list. You could avoid assigning 'data' a value by passing the value to the constructor in the initialization list.

error.msg: The scope of the variable 'dataRef' can be reduced.
error.verbose: The scope of the variable 'dataRef' can be reduced. Warning: Be careful when fixing this message, especially when there are inner loops. Here is an example where cppcheck will write that the scope for 'i' can be reduced:\012void f(int x)\012{\012 int i = 0;\012 if (x) {\012 // it's safe to move 'int i = 0;' here\012 for (int n = 0; n < 10; ++n) {\012 // it is possible but not safe to move 'int i = 0;' here\012 do_something(&i);\012 }\012 }\012}\012When you see this message it is always safe to reduce the variable scope 1 level.

error.msg: Class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__listen_socket_82_base' which is inherited by class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__listen_socket_82_bad' does not have a virtual destructor.
error.verbose: Class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__listen_socket_82_base' which is inherited by class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__listen_socket_82_bad' does not have a virtual destructor. If you destroy instances of the derived class by deleting a pointer that points to the base class, only the destructor of the base class is executed. Thus, dynamic memory that is managed by the derived class could leak. This can be avoided by adding a virtual destructor to the base class.

error.msg: Class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__listen_socket_82_base' which is inherited by class 'CWE123_Write_What_Where_Condition__listen_socket_82_goodG2B' does not have a virtual destructor.

error.msg: Variable 'data' is assigned in constructor body. Consider performing initialization in initialization list.
error.verbose: When an object of a class is created, the constructors of all member variables are called consecutively in the order the variables are declared, even if you don't explicitly write them to the initialization list. You could avoid assigning 'data' a value by passing the value to the constructor in the initialization list.

error.msg: Cppcheck cannot find all the include files (use --check-config for details)
error.verbose: Cppcheck cannot find all the include files. Cppcheck can check the code without the include files found. But the results will probably be more accurate if all the include files are found. Please check your project's include directories and add all of them as include directories for Cppcheck. To see what files Cppcheck cannot find use --check-config.
